Hepatocellular Cancer (HCC)_1:
Description 1:
    A 62-year-old male patient, of Asian ethnicity, with a history of chronic hepatitis B infection, presented with intermittent dull ache in the upper right quadrant of the abdomen, which he rated as 5/10 on the pain scale. The discomfort has been persistent for the past three months and is often accompanied by unexplained weight loss of 8 pounds during the same period. The patient has a known diagnosis of cirrhosis for the last four years, and he has been regularly monitored for the progression of liver disease. His alpha-fetoprotein levels have shown a rising trend during the past six months. Despite being asymptomatic, the patient's age, gender, ethnicity, history of hepatitis B infection, cirrhosis, and the observed increase in alpha-fetoprotein levels necessitate a comprehensive diagnostic workup to assess the presence of hepatocellular cancer.
Hepatocellular Cancer (HCC)_2:
Description 2:
    A 58-year-old female patient, diagnosed with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), presented with a persistent, dull abdominal pain localized in the right upper quadrant, which she described as 4/10 in intensity. The discomfort has been ongoing for the last two months and is often accompanied by a feeling of fullness after consuming small meals. The patient's medical history is significant for obesity and type 2 diabetes, both of which are well-managed with lifestyle modifications and medication. She has no history of viral hepatitis. Despite the absence of overt symptoms, the combination of her age, gender, NASH diagnosis, and the reported abdominal pain warrants a thorough evaluation to rule out hepatocellular cancer.
Hepatocellular Cancer (HCC)_3:
Description 3:
    A 48-year-old male patient, co-infected with HIV and hepatitis C virus (HCV), presented with a persistent, dull ache in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, which he rated as 6/10 in severity. The pain has been present for the last four months and is associated with intermittent episodes of nausea. The patient's medical history is notable for HCV infection, which has been effectively treated and cleared two years ago. He is currently on antiretroviral therapy for HIV. Despite the successful clearance of HCV, the persistence of abdominal pain in the context of the patient's co-infection with HCV and HIV necessitates a comprehensive diagnostic assessment to evaluate the possibility of hepatocellular cancer.
